column5: ['News', 'bloomberg', 'quicktake', 'business', 'bloomberg quicktake', 'quicktake originals', 'bloomberg\nquicktake by bloomberg', 'documentary', 'mini documentary', 'mini doc', 'doc', 'us news', 'world news', 'finance', 'science']
column13: Because we didn't have anything,  we have to come up with  something just to survive.  Since the beginning of full-scale invasion,  people used pretty much everything.  They used civilian cars to stop tanks. They used Molotov cocktails. And they used simple civilian drones. In Ukraine, unmanned aerial vehicles - drones - have become a critical part of the country's defense. Drones have brought a new  dimension to tactics in warfare in the 21st century, in particular in strategy, we have the ability to see the  enemy online here and now. And thus to strike it quickly. They have come to epitomize the David versus Goliath battle Ukraine has found itself in. A battle which has seen the country develop a host of cheap and disruptive technologies that has, until recently, kept Russia at bay. A simple FPV drone is like AK-47 today.  It‚Äôs working, it's very cheap.  Then, in January 2024, Ukraine's military released remarkable footage: The sinking of a Russian warship by a naval drone worth a tiny fraction of its target. As well as technological, drones also indicate an economic shift in how wars are now being fought. When you have drone for like 500 bucks  versus tank for three million  bucks and drone wins, it just doesn't make sense to buy more tanks. Ukraine's war has spawned an industry of startup defense companies and grassroots volunteers; many of whom are not just making a difference, but taking the fight to Russia itself. We have been doing great work so far, hitting targets across the border. And, I think, we're going to continue to increase the scale and volume of those strikes. On Ukraine's frontline near Bakhmut, the Achilles drone squadron of the 92nd Assault Brigade  are seeking out Russian positions just a few hundred meters away. Please, look here. The enemy soldier  is now moving between positions,  he has already been spotted. Shortly, he will be hit either by artillery  or, we are now adjusting the drone  strike on their positions. The Achilles squadron's main task is aerial reconnaissance. Save a few software adjustments, they use a pretty standard FPV, a first-person view drone. Invented for hobbyists and racing, it has four propellers and a camera that streams live footage back to a pilot on the ground. These types of drone are readily available to buy in electronics stores all over the world for just a few hundred dollars. Not long after Russia's full-scale invasion in 2022, Ukrainians started taping grenades and other explosives to FPVs - a cheap and lethal solution that has proven extremely effective in defending against Russian offensives. Flying at speeds of up to 100mph on Ukraine's frontline, they're now known as "kamikazes". The enemy is panicking and fearing all of this. There is less and less movement  along the collision line. For Ukraine's defense, it's become a numbers game. How we think about it,  not in drone price,  but in one dead Russian per one dollar.  One FPV can destroy the armor vehicle. And if you talk about two or three  drones, you can destroy the tank. Oleksiy Babenko runs one of the more than 100 underground drone manufacturers in Ukraine. They‚Äôre part of a complex network of volunteers and entrepreneurs, as well as soldiers who provide real-time feedback from the front. Technicians  bolt and solder motors, cameras and motherboards. 3D printers make new frames. When a drone is completed, it‚Äôs brought upstairs for a quick test. Then it's set aside for packaging  and delivery to the front. The kill chain from manufacturer to killing  can be less than one week. That‚Äôs despite issues around sourcing parts. Because so many of the world's commercial and civilian drones are made in China, Russia's ally,  producers like Babenko still depend  on some Chinese-made parts. While they managed to mostly bypass Beijing's embargo, shipping through other countries in Europe, they're finding ways to become more independent. A year before now it was all Chinese components.  Now, we have good Ukrainian frame  that cost not so much. If you talk about propellers,  in Ukraine it cost less than Chinese propellers  and I think it's better propellers than Chinese. Of course, Chinese make more electronics  so it's cheaper to make it in China. But I hope soon we'll make it cheaper,  cheaper and cheaper.  Babenko let us film in his warehouse because he's about to move to a larger facility to keep up with demand. They currently make 6,000 kamikaze drones a month. President Zelenskiy has called on drone makers to churn out a million machines this year. Babenko is bullish. Our country will produce more than two million  or maybe up to three million drones for this year.  As the war has progressed, so have the drones. It's rare to see grenades with duct tape these days. Every week, Maxim Sheremet and his team from Dronarnia, a self-described ‚ÄúUAV lab‚Äù, travel to a secret location outside of Kyiv. We must test all of this stuff.  When you fly in the drone  you must understand,  for example; low batteries, low altitude,  wind velocity, enemy weapons,  problems with some electronic stuff. Now, the drones are full of advanced technology. As well as FPVs used as kamikazes, they test other types of drone, such as the 'Vampire'. While slower, it is much bigger and capable of carrying a larger payload. Crucially, it's equipped with thermal imaging to see in the dark. Russian soldiers liken it  to a mythical witch who eats children in the night. Baba Yaga. It's a nightmare of Russia.  When our Vampire drone is in the air,  the infantry in the trenches know   that the enemy is ******. But with any change in warfare, the enemy usually adapts too.  At Dronarnia‚Äôs lab, volunteers dissect Russian drones recovered from the battlefield to better understand the technology. And they have to, since drones became an integral part of this war, Russia now produces more than Ukraine. It also imports Iranian-developed Shahed models. We're losing in numbers, in numbers. Russians start to manufacture  a lot of kamikazes.  It's places like Dronarnia where Ukraine finds an edge in the drone war. From advanced wireless chips to reusable drones and extending flight range with new antenna technology. For example in Mavics, DJI drone video transmitter is 100 milliwatts. This is 3,000 milliwatts. So the power of video transmitter of this drone is more than 10x powerful. We teach our military guy actually in this classroom how to be a UAV engineer.  Not how to fly, but how to create their own drone. I told my students, our rifles is our brain.  They still find plenty of ways to innovate with whatever they can get their hands on too. We use these batteries from the vape in this dropping mechanism. When you turning on the flashlight on the drone,  the dropping system activate and the grenade are falling down. A common theme among Ukraine's new class of arms dealers is that nobody ever thought they'd be making weapons. Software engineer Luba Shipovich left the US, where she ran a successful IT outsourcing company, to return to Ukraine. She co-founded Dignitas, one of the biggest volunteer organizations funding drone makers. Development of IT sector,  it was the fourth-biggest sector in Ukraine  before the full-scale invasion.  So it's natural that all these engineer, software engineers, hardware engineers, some of them joined the army,   others started to work for defense sector to come up with some solutions. Francisco Serra-Martins, an Australian venture capitalist, used to serve on the board of a nonprofit that made drones delivering emergency supplies in Africa. Now, he makes drones that blow  up Russian infrastructure. If you have a patient that's been shot and you need to stop it at the source, and for us, providing medical aid is definitely an important, goal, but we need to stop Russians from sending missiles and armor and infantry across the border. Terminal autonomy‚Äôs drones are guided by a system similar to that of an American Tomahawk cruise missile. The weapons have been used to devastating effect in strikes on Russian oil refineries, but unlike a tomahawk, which costs about $2 million,  Terminal Autonomy‚Äôs AQ 400 Scythe sells for about $30,000.  How? Not only are these drones powered by the type of chips you can find in a dishwasher, they're not demanding excessive profit margins. Cyberlux is one of the largest loitering munitions contracts in the US, if not the largest. They're selling a $500 drone for $50,000, whereas we sell that for 10% profit. It's basically cutting that fat off the top, and then producing on a massive scale. that's what we're doing. We're not doing any broader innovation than other defense companies, we just price strategically quite differently. What companies like Terminal Autonomy do reveal is how much the industry has evolved since Russia's invasion and how conflicts might look in the future. There's no pilot. The long range strategic effects Are basically fire and forget. They can visually identify targets and then navigate through a camera. There is no pilot, no crew. If they get shot down, economically it's a win because they're cheaper than anything the Russians can use to shoot it down. it's basically a new form of like attrition warfare where these systems can be deployed in massive volumes against strategic sites. Raising the cost of Russia's invasion is part of Kyiv‚Äôs strategy, but whether it can compete with the substantially better-resourced Russian army employing similar tactics remains to be seen. Arguably more important though, is keeping up the supply of drones. During the many months Republicans in the US Congress blocked military aid to Ukraine, UAVs played a crucial role in halting Russian advances and kept many more Ukrainians alive. While we were waiting for artillery  supplies from our partners, the FPV drones practically saved the front line. But drones, even with their technological advances, can only go so far in keeping Ukraine in this war. Though the Biden administration finally freed up substantial military aid, these are still desperate times for Ukraine's military. Their soldiers will need much more from the West, if they‚Äôre to turn the tide against Russia.

column2: The Tri Folding Phone Impressions!
column3:
Huawei Mate XT is the tri-fold phone, a concept come to life

Shoutout to dbrand for finding a way to buy this thing. They make skins for other phones: http://dbrand.com

MKBHD Merch: http://shop.MKBHD.com

Tech I'm using right now: https://www.amazon.com/shop/MKBHD

Intro Track: http://youtube.com/20syl
Playlist of MKBHD Intro music: https://goo.gl/B3AWV5

~
http://twitter.com/MKBHD
http://instagram.com/MKBHD
http://facebook.com/MKBHD
column5: ['tri fold', 'triple fold', 'tri fold phone', 'Huawei Mate XT', 'Mate XT', 'MKBHD']
column13: (shapes springing) (bright electronic music) - All right, so you've heard of flipping phones, you've heard of folding phones, but technology never slows down. So welcome to a phone with both. The world's first tri-fold phone. This thing, this is the Huawei Mate XT, is what it's called. So I'd heard about this thing, I'd seen some videos online, but it was also a Huawei phone, so it was China-only. So knowing that I'm never gonna daily-drive it, I didn't wanna, like, get too caught up. But it's so interesting. Like, I just had so many questions like, what is it like to use? What are the creases like? Like, what are the trade-offs? How hard is it to carry a triple-folding phone? What are the case is like? Why is it called a tri-fold when it only technically folds twice? I need answers. So I was like, "All right, I need to get my hands on one." I reached out to dbrand and asked, like, "Can you guys get me a contact where I can buy one?" And I never asked questions, but they're always able to pull it off. And they did. So I spent the money, I imported the thing, and now I can give you a tour of the tri-fold experience. So let us start with just when it's closed, right? When it's closed, you have a pretty reasonable 6.4-inch-sized phone. Well, I mean, you know, reasonable from the front anyway. If you're just looking at it, using it, the screen gets plenty bright. It is 90 hertz. And then, somehow, the bezels are pretty thin and even all the way around. The top and the bottom, the left and the right. And actually, of course, the right side is the screen curving around the edge, so the software appropriately creates a fourth bezel to match. And it looks honestly more like a normal phone than a lot of the other foldables out there. So then, using it, you know, you pretty quickly feel that it is thicker than a normal phone. But what's crazy is each of these slices (chuckles) individually is ridiculously thin, about four millimeters. So, in total, they add up to 13 millimeters thick when it's closed. Which would be pretty thick if it was a slab phone, but that's actually about the same as a lot of the other single folds, like the Z Fold 6. So then the power button/fingerprint reader combo button and the volume buttons on the right side here, they're pushed a little bit back of the center. Not the end of the world. Totally usable. You're obviously gonna notice that parts of the screen are a bit exposed and vulnerable if you're gonna put it in a pocket or in a backpack or something. But overall, just as a regular-sized single-screen smartphone experience, this is actually really respectable. This is like an eight out of 10, really close to the best I've seen, which is awesome. But then you open it for the first time, and from here, you get to the small tablet mode. So, yes, size-wise, now we're basically matching a lot of the other folding phones out there, like Pixel Fold, Samsung Z Fold, et cetera. This is a 7.9-inch diagonal, that is roughly a square aspect ratio. I'll be honest, it looks fine, but I actually don't really think it was meant to operate in this form factor most of the time. I mean, why stop halfway when you're just one more fold away from greatness? But it is clearly perfectly usable like this. The crease, your first crease, is impressively small and very easy to ignore when you're actually using it. But yeah, thin bezels all the way around. Again, blacked-out pixels on the far left-hand side this time. And there's also still a couple little folding phone tricks, like, of course, since the main camera is on the back and there's no selfie camera on these two panes, then this is the perfect time to take a selfie with the main camera, but get a full-sized preview on the 6.4-inch screen that's still wrapped around the other side. And they are really good flagship quality triple cameras, by the way. I'll get to that in a second. You, of course, get all the other benefits of the display spec: the brightness, the 90 hertz. It's really solid. Obviously, it's just a little awkward that, like, it's twice as thick in one hand as the other, which is a little unbalanced. And then, it is glass on one side and then, the, like, sort of leather material on the other. So, it's a little bit weird in that way, but honestly, still very impressive. I feel like this is like a seven out of 10. Still pretty close, but you know, we're not done. So this is what we're all here for, the final fold, which opens this thing up to a full 10.2-inch corner-to-corner display. So this is now a full 3,184 by 2,232 90-hertz OLED display, thin bezels all the way around, amazingly, with a hole-punch selfie camera over to the left side, two creases, two hinges. And yeah, this is not an iPad Mini-sized screen in your pocket. This is literally a full-sized 10-inch tablet in your pocket, which is actually incredible. Now, the more you play with it, the more you start to notice little quirks, like, first of all, it's ridiculously thin now that it's all open. It's actually kind of disorienting to hold the tablet with a screen this big, but bezels this small, and, like, the whole thing is this thin, it's just kind of a marvel. And then you look at the creases plural, 'cause now you got two, and you can actually see there is a small difference between the inward folding crease on the right side and the outward folding crease on the left. But they are also, actually, both impressively small. But, like, yeah, this... I'm actually kind of sad that I can't, like, fully daily drive something like this 'cause it is Huawei. Like, you can kind of hack your way into getting some Google services on here. But a lot of this UI, a lot of this OS is still Chinese only. Like, it's not gonna be great. It's probably missing some bands in the US, too. But just, wow. It's a good amount of software tweaks for the triple-fold thing, too. Like when you fully unfold it, the whole UI stretches out but is still one page on each side. So they've kind of just played this animation to stretch out two pages among three panels, but the animation's pretty smooth. And there is a wrong way to fold it, too, by the way. And it tells you about it. So obviously, you can close it pretty easily. The correct way to unfold it is to get the two on the inside, but if you unfold it the wrong way, like that, it actually tells you. It says, "Fold it a different way to use the device, please. You're kind of doing something weird here." Which totally fair, I'll get it right next time. You kind of have to... There is a little learning curve to according... "According?" Accordioning quickly every time. But yeah, this has to be a 10 out of 10. I mean, there's the fact that I'm able to fit a, look at the size of this, a 10-inch display, reasonably in my pocket. That by itself is something that no other device can do. So I gotta love that. Another question I had early when playing with this is... I mean, people put cases on every phone. What are cases for this phone like? Turns out it does come with a case in the box, which is this thing. And so, really, it is just one back piece of the phone that it can protect when it's fully closed. So this case snaps onto the back of the phone like this and then protects also a little bit of the exposed screen on the side, so it makes sense. They don't wanna get any debris in there. And then it has a kickstand on the back, which can rotate around and support it at a couple of various different angles. So you can watch videos like this if you're into that. And it can also rotate out of the way to expose the wireless charging coils because it turns out this phone also has wireless charging, and if you just flip it sideways on certain charges, you can get it to line up and work with wireless charging. So that's one type of person who will use the kickstand built into the case. But there is another type of person, by the way, a total reckless psycho that would unfold it like this and then use the phone itself as a built-in kickstand. And it totally works. Like, the UI responds to it, and you can watch, you know, YouTube on a larger part of the screen, but you're also totally scratching the outside part of the screen you're using as a kickstand. So yeah, I'm obviously not gonna recommend that. In case you're also wondering about specs on something like this. It's fit flagship specs inside, despite being these crazy thin slivers of a phone. It's the flagship seven-nanometer Kirin 9010 chip made by Huawei. It is also up to 16 gigs of RAM and a terabyte of storage, which is crazy. And triple cameras on the back, as you can see. That's a 50-megapixel main camera, a 12-megapixel ultra-wide, and a telephoto. And there's a 5,600 milliamp-hour battery chopped up and distributed in here with 67-watt fast charging and 50-watt wireless charging, which is kind of insane. And then the whole thing will retail... It's in China, so if you sort of do the conversion price, this, like, top-end model with the terabyte of storage is like $3,500. So $3,000 to $3,500 US. That's actually not that much more expensive than some of the highest-end folds that we have. So why is this the only tri-fold phone? Maybe that's the main question you're wondering after all of this. Because it's so cool. It's just the fact that I can actually fit all of this in the dimensions of something that fits in my pocket is nuts. And they've done a lot of things with, like, nice software touches that actually make it feel really well-considered. But yeah, there are also some trade-offs, of course. I think the biggest weakness on paper is gonna be the battery, the 5,600 milliamp-hour battery. You know, fast charging is great, obviously, so that can offset it. But the more time you use this wide open with the 10 inches of screen, the tougher that's gonna be on the battery. You know, if you look at typical larger tablets, even the thin ones, the 10-inch tablets are having, like, 8,000-plus milliamp-hour batteries pretty often. So that's probably the biggest weakness here. The speakers are also truly terrible. It's interesting 'cause they come out of the right-hand corner and the left-hand corner when it's open, but it's so thin, there's just... It's physics, there's not enough room for big chambers for huge speakers. So, yeah, the speakers are pretty tinny, pretty bad. And then, there is no IP rating for dust or water resistance. Some of the newer foldables have water resistance now. This one, not so much. And then, of course, the price is obviously gonna keep some people away. But honestly, that's a pretty small list of trade-offs for something that is so, like, shockingly different and new, that I'm impressed. This had the potential to be like the world's greatest concept phone. Remember concept phones from a couple years ago? I was like, it's getting kind of weird that people are, like, showing off phones they're never gonna make. This could have been the coolest concept phone ever. But then they just went and decided to actually make a bunch of them and ship 'em. This phone also just happens to have a variable aperture lens on the main camera, so it can switch between f/1.4 wide open for some real background bokeh to f/4 and getting more things in focus. It happens to also have that insanely fast charging. It comes with an 80-watt charging brick, and it has fast wireless charging in a body barely thick enough to have an entire USB-C port. It happens to come with this pre-installed screen protector that I'm just never gonna remove. It's crazy. There's just so much going on here that in this world of so many phones just being, "Oh, all phones are the same these days. It's just a little different from last year. Not a whole lot has changed," I gotta hand it to projects like this. This is just insane. (laughs) They didn't have to go this hard. They didn't have to go this hard, but they did. Thanks for watching. Catch you guys in the next one. Peace. (bright electronic music)

column13: [Music] it's that time of year again where I'm going to go over all of my favorite tech of the year but I'm not going to just talk about my favorites I also wanted to talk about some stuff which I thought was pretty average and some stuff which I just outright didn't like this list is technically part two because I did a Midway check-in through the year so go and check out that video as well I'll link it in the description below and as ever not all of this stuff came out this year but it was new to me or new to the channel in some way anyway let's get started with the best tech okay first on the list is the DJI osmo 3 Pocket this is a small powerful well-developed camera which is just an absolute joy to use and honestly I was really hesitant to buy this and I didn't think I would like it as much as I did I took it with me on a trip to Japan I had recently and it let me capture so much more stuff in the moment than I would normally capture the footage looks excellent as well I throw some up here so you can see but even in the dark the footage looked much better than my phone did and I really really enjoyed it for that and the best thing is it's so easy to use I could just pass it to anyone and they could film this nice stable footage which is something you can't really get with a big DSLR or something like that and for me I don't actually like leaving my phone on the side to film myself or to Vlog with it or anything like that but I don't mind leaving this hanging around because it's not my phone and you know I don't mind if it gets knocked over or something like that I don't have to baby it as much it's really nice and tactile to use to switch on you just flip the screen and you ready to go and you can also flip it again and then just go straight into vertical mode if you want to capture footage for Instagram or Tik Tok or anything like that I actually picked up the Creator Edition which gives you this nice little case of wideangle lens a wireless microphone a battery extender and a tripod and this neat little bag as well so you pretty much got absolutely everything you need to get started making content and it all just snaps really neatly together so it's the smallest little setup and the quality is just fantastic so yeah that was one of my top picks for this here absolutely excellent device next up is something you're probably all expecting to see if you've watched this channel for any amount of time but it's the new M4 iPad Pro and specifically the 11-in version this is Apple really showing off in my opinion this is the best hardware that they make at the moment the fact that something can be this slim and this powerful it's just kind of insane and the fact that you don't have to buy the biggest version now to get the best screen is just wonderful I love the updates did with the pencil Pro I think the hardware updates are just insane this thing is so slim and so light it's just a joy to take around I still think there's more that Apple can do with the software especially with external monitor support and some other strange little niggles that the software seems to have but overall Apple nailed this update and I came from my M1 iPad Pro to this M4 and it felt like a really good jump and yeah the 11in size now is just perfect for me moving on from there is the iPhone 16 Pro Max and yes I'll be the first to admit that this wasn't a huge update from the 15 Pro Max I got the same color and everything so it pretty much looks exactly the same but it's not for the features you'd expect I actually think the camera control update which was one of the main new features was a little bit of a miss this year it's kind of tricky to use and honestly I forgot about it pretty much directly after review but I absolutely have to Hype up the battery life on this thing this year it has been insane being able to walk around all of Tokyo all day while I'm smashing the camera and Google Maps and filming everything that I saw and then getting back to the hotel relatively late and still having like 20 or 30% left in the battery just gave me so much confidence whenever I went out and I never thought about the battery I never had to worry about getting an external power bank or anything like that this was a really beautiful travel companion and not to mention this year the camera is still equally great it's probably better than it was last year and some of the photos I got on this phone while I was out there I'm genuinely so happy with iPhones really kill it when it comes to landscape photography and I got some really nice photos of Mount Fuji that I'm so happy with so that's why it made this list next up is one of my newer inclusions and that's video games earlier in the year I was playing through Hades 2 on my steam deck and I absolutely loved that and I've recently been playing animal well on there as well which has been great but there's one game I really did want to highlight and that's the Legend of Zelda Echoes of wisdom this time you control Zelda instead of link and you have your own set of powers and moves which are completely different and it's a really enjoyable way to play through a Zelda title like I'm a huge Zelda fan I was going to like this game anyway but the art style is absolutely gorgeous the music in this game as well was just fantastic and I really enjoyed the story and the entire ending sequence of this game I think was one of the funnest I've ever done in a Zelda game so if you haven't played it I do really recommend it this game isn't free from problems though I tend to find I was using the same Echoes over and over again but overall this was a wonderful little side Adventure in the Zelda universe and if you've got a switch I highly recommend playing it next up I wanted to talk about a couple of watches I picked up this year which I really like and watches are still Tech so they're going to be included in this video anyway the first one which I'm really happy with and I picked this up when I was out in Japan is this one I'm wearing right now this is from a brand called qo and I really hope I'm saying their name right but they had a shop in Kyoto and the shop was unlike any other watch shop I've been in you went in there and everything was just completely laid out so you could pick any watch face and pick any strap and try them on your wrist and just have a really nice brows I ended up going for the old Smith 9009 which is based off old British military watches and I really love how it looks I'll speak a little bit more about this in my next video so if that's already up I'll link it below but the experience really was wonderful the second watch I picked up this year and yes it's obviously turning into some sort of problem with me now but I actually got another Moon Swatch Swatch put out some more models this year and this mission on Earth desert one I just could not resist I don't have a watch with this specific colorway so this was a really nice addition to my collection and like I know there's a lot of hate out there for the moon Swatch and I totally get it these are very much overpriced for what they are but I really like the moon swatches they help me get into the watch hobby as a whole and they're a really nice entry point for someone like me so for that reason I still love them and I really do like this piece too next up is the wonderfully surprising M4 Mac Mini I love it when Apple pushes what's possible of the M series chips and this is a clear show of that it's is unbelievably small you really kind of have to hold it to feel that it reminds me of a baby Max studio and putting them next to each other is almost comical not to mention you can also upgrade this to become a pretty powerful machine if you want to but I think it kind of makes best sense in its base configuration because once you start adding stuff the price does start flying up quick but I think the entry price is really decent this is about 600 here in the UK and it's a fully fledged Mac getting the M4 chip in here 16 G gab of ram you're still only getting 256 GB of storage which is probably the only mess but otherwise this is a crazy powerful introduction to using a Mac and if it's your first Mac I can't think of a better way to go you can just slide it into your current PC setup and use the same Monitor and keyboard and mouse and get started with Mac to put it in perspective this is cheaper than my first MacBook was back in 2006 and it's about a million times better which is just wild to think about but yeah a very cool new Mac that makes access to the Apple ecosystem cheaper than it's been for a long time okay my last thing on my favorite tech of the year is something I'll have to grab so bear with me is this Tom Delong signature Fender Starcaster I'm a huge blink fan there's no doubt about that and when Fender put out this signature guitar earlier in the year I knew I would just end up with one and if you followed me on Instagram or YouTube for a while you'll know that this color is just synonymous with everything I do on the channel so when I saw it come in this color I was like oh no and I've got to admit I absolutely love the styling on this guitar it's a bit strange cuz it's only got the one pickup in the bridge position so it's kind of pretty much built for Punk rot which makes sense but it's got this lovely roasted sort of neck which is really nice it's got the white accent knob which looks great and it's got the lovely white binding throughout the whole thing and also to really finish it off it's got Tom written on the back obviously because it's the tomong signature but the fact that's also my name as well just kind of made this an absolute purchase for me that I couldn't resist and yeah you can get a much better guitar for the money I wrestled with that for a long time before picking this up eventually but this one has been beautiful and it's really filled a nice Gap in our studio even though I am a basist this has still been lovely to pick up and play and a better play right now to prove that I actually can let's move to the honorable mentions because there were two things I wanted to talk about and they're both budget devices which I think were awesome first up is the cmf1 phone from nothing this phone introduced not only a really crazy low price but it really brought back customization to kind of phones in general you can swap this back plate out for pretty much any other color that you can imagine you can undo this button here to attach things like a lanyard or a stand or like a wallet which sits on the back and they also released the 3D printer kind of designs for it and people came up with loads of weird stuff like a fan that you can use and like a measuring tape and pretty much anything you can imagine and it was a really decent phone to boot so a great device is there from nothing great color too and the other thing as well is from nothing too this was the nothing phone 2A a really really cool and interesting design seriously I don't know any other phone which looks quite like that and it came in at a really decent price as well and it gave you loads for it the screen was great the processor was decent and the camera was enough to get byy on I've often said if I wasn't an iPhone user I think nothing is where I would go for phones because they just look so interesting and different and the software experience on them is really nice too so those are my two honorable mentions two phones from nothing both really really great all right let's talk about the me Tech the stuff which was just kind of okay or nearly really good or just not quite there and first up is the airpods max with USBC and I really really wanted to like these I think they're built really nicely and I much prefer the sound over my Sony XM 4S which I struggled with last year and the Apple ecosystem around it is amazing like I can switch between my Mac and my phone and my iPad without even having to think about it I just pick it up and these connect to it immediately but they're just way too heavy and way too bulky if you put these into a bag you can really feel it and you don't have that with other headphones I took these with me on the 15 hour flight to Japan and another trip which I took to Germany and while the noise cancellation on the plane is fantastic they just don't fold in any meaningful way and also the carrying case is just kind of a bit weird here in the studio though they're actually really nice to use especially if you're a Mac User because there's next to no latency on them so I can edit videos with these on and it's wonderful but I feel like apple could have done so much more of these this was the first update to airpods Max in 4 years and all they did was kind of put USBC on them and that was it nine times out of 10 when I taken these with me I just feel like I should have just taken my airpods Pro and put them in my pocket rather than like these around okay next up on the list is the iPad Mini 7 this is actually the iPad Mini 6 because I didn't end up picking up a mini 7 and that's kind of why it's in this category it was basically a spec bump model from Apple it went up to the A7 Pro chip which is a really powerful chip and it also moved to the apple pencil Pro which I really like and really appreciate I think the pencil Pro is an a upgrade but otherwise that was kind of it for the iPad Mini there wasn't any other changes it was more just an update to make sure Apple intelligence works on it which is great don't get me wrong but I feel like they just did enough to keep this one alive and I think that brings me to the main point about the mini is I actually think we're lucky to even have this device anymore and I'm glad it hasn't gone the way of the iPhone Mini yet and just been completely axed or at least not yet but it basically means that this update is going to keep it going for another 2 3 or 4 years or something like that before it either gets replaced with something or it just gets completely cancelled so yeah that's why it's on this list it was just a kind of okay update and otherwise it was pretty much exactly the same lastly in the meh category for me is the steam deck OLED I bought this late last year so I couldn't include it in any of those kind of videos at all and to be honest this has been sitting in my bad tech for the year for a while and very quickly one of the reasons I don't like it is I find the battery life just really poor on this OLED version at least I seem to get about 2 and 1/ half to 3 hours of play time before it jumps out and that translates to the standby as well I can put this on standby with like full charge and then two or 3 days later it's completely gone the other thing which I didn't particularly like either were the placements of the buttons especially the abxy they feel like they're kind of falling off the console I'm also not a person that uses the touchpads at all on any of the games I'm playing so that bit of the console at least for me just felt like kind of misused space but my view has softened because it's introduced me to some fantastic games Hades 2 on here was a big one for me and I absolutely loved that and I've recently been playing animal well on here too and this big OLED to play things on is just wonderful and finally why my view really has softened on it is because so many people have been reintroduced to gaming through the steam deck people that didn't have time before used to love playing PC games or something like that have been able to pick this up and be reintroduced to the joys of gaming and you know how can I be down on that that's a fantastic thing so yeah the steam deck probably just wasn't the console for me but I think I really like what it represents and I think the future of this sort of console is going to be awesome okay it's time for the bad Tech or the tech that I didn't really connect with but before we get started I did want to say just because I didn't like it it doesn't mean it's a bad piece of technology at all and I feel like I'm going to make some enemies from saying this anyway but I didn't like the Fujifilm x16 this year at all now don't get me wrong this is a fantastic camera the picture quality is insane The Styling of the camera is really nice and Fuji's colors are absolutely beautiful but the main thing I struggled with on this camera was the 35 mm to focal length I tend to find that focal length isn't wide enough to be a true Y and it's not close enough to kind of get nice portrait photos and I constantly felt like I wasn't really getting the shots I wanted out of it which I totally realize is on me it does have a nice digital Zoom which I was using quite a lot to zoom in a little bit to 50 mil and then up to like 70 or 80 but the picture quality does drop off when you use that and I also found the auto focus on this was just pretty slow especially compared to my Sony a74 I was just missing shots here and there because it wasn't getting enough time to quickly focus on what I wanted it to focus on now I did get some bangers of this some which I'm really happy with and I much preferred carrying this around with me I just had it in a bag or I was holding it and it drew loads of attention as well so many people asked me about this when I was out there but yeah I just couldn't connect with this this year I was also a little bit worried about the build quality as well and I'll try and show this on camera but my shutter button feels really really loose and this kind of front section as a whole just feels a little bit kind of plasticky when it shouldn't you know this was an expensive camera so I don't really like feeling that either so there you have it there's my favorite tech my kind of Middle of the Road Tech and the kind of tech I didn't really like this year I hope you enjoyed the video if you did pop a like and also let me know in the comments below what your favorites and least favorites have been for the year because I always love to see what you have to say and I will see you all in the next one oh [Music]

options let you create genuine masterpieces your neighbors will be envious [Music] amazing advancements are happening in the realm of balconies worthy of discussion at least in construction circles and a great example is the glide on cassette these balconies are sturdy attractive and so technologically advanced that the installation record stands at just a minute and 34 seconds Builders love that glide on cassette balconies come fully assembled so all that's left is installing them on special anchors now even large scale projects like building 474 balconies in the neo2 building are no problem plus to help the environment glide on cassette features a low carbon frame that cuts CO2 emissions by 19% in certain production stages [Music] we're in Colorado on a section of Highway 36 the body confirms the sleeves Effectiveness for 20 years [Music] forget Scott Pilgrim the true excitement is Mario versus the world particularly when it foes are plaster steel and other materials that and Expansion Joints even on flowing [Music] water Mappy Flex ms45 outperforms the famous adhesive tape from the meme and even with a 3mm layer thickness guarantees a flexible and robust Bond [Music] [Music] in France last year a house was built using sunflowers and salt as an unconventional approach to addressing the climate crisis however today we'll be discussing a more practical solution the Seeker block formwork this eco-friendly product is made from bioplastic and recycled materials and it's designed to protect Mason's backs and muscles since each assembled block weighs only 22 kg the assembly process is so simple that one worker can build 60 square m in just a day plus Seeker block is incredibly strong and can even be used in elevator construction [Music] it's often said that with screws and just like that you're done no need for Mortar and you can work in any weather plus the resulting facade is more than twice as strong as a traditional one in terms of compressive strength [Music] concrete work has been highly sought after in the United States for quite a while over 60% of Roads along with sidewalks garages and other spots use concrete unfortunately a common issue is the sinking of concrete slabs which can lead to cracking if not depressed imagine the impact that this occurs on a heavily traffic Road luckily repair teams equipped with poly level have a ones playgrounds require a safe smooth and adequately cushioned surface wet pore effectively combines all of its traits its foundation is top quality rubber from the UK and Western Europe it's non-toxic and when installed correctly with a 15 mm thick top layer it can even with stand spiked shoes so don't be shocked if you encounter wet Pour at a climbing facility or a racetrack like the previous product it comes in various colors allowing designers to freely Express their creativity for each project [Music] over 900 customers across eight European countries are already enjoying ronia houses they're made from four modules but can serve as Living Spaces Wine sellers and even saers if needed they can be expanded to cover hundreds of square me sometimes Builders finish a ronia house in just 24 hours the modules are made of reinforced concrete at least 9 cm thick allowing for a meter of flooring on top plus they have an estimated lifespan of about 100 years [Music] build and lift is a construction method where the roof is built on the ground first and then lifted into place using special [Music] Jacks this approach has benefits for both workers and clients workers don't have to work at Heights reducing the risk of Falls and injuries and clients will appreciate that it only takes one day to lift the roof of a 250 S M house and most of the time no scaffolding is required as column2: Aap iPhone user ho ya android? ü§î #ios #apple #shorts #tech #awareness #smartphone
column13: If you or anybody close  to you is buying an iPhone, Then be careful before only, Because before the  launch of iPhone 16, It's duplicate seals have  arrived in the market. By using these, Some shopkeepers, Will sell the open  boxes, by resealing it. Then it can be imported  from other countries, Or can be a used phone. You will open the  seal by your own, So, you will feel  it is a new iPhone. This is so wrong man. To avoid these frauds, So, keep these  things in your mind. Number 1, Try to purchase a new iPhone, from Apple  authorized stores. Or anyone who  you know very well. Number 2, Check the Apple website  for the phone's serial number. To see if is  activated earlier or not. And is the warranty left or not. Number 3, Do check the model no.,  in your phone's settings. You have to check  the first alphabet, Here "M" means new, "F" means refurbished, And the last 2 letter  tells us the country, Share this and spread  this info to everyone, And save this  for your future iPhone. Subscribe to Tech iELA.

column13: apple is working on a huge lineup of products for early 2025 potentially going into a January event which sounds crazy but according to the leaks and rumors and the fact that Apple released the M2 MacBook Pros in January of 2022 it could actually happen so in this video I'm going to go through and explain seven brand new Apple products in the pipeline that are rumored to come as soon as early next year and for each of them I'm going to explain the main changes and the features that you need to know about product number one is the M4 MacBook Air now this one gets updated basically every year the current one came in the springtime but this time around we could actually see it come even sooner according to the most reliable app leaker out there mark German he says that this new Macbook here could come as soon as January which is a huge surprise and he even said the Mac Studio will come later between March and June and he also confirmed a few days ago that these new Macbook ears have already been in production 4 weeks now so with that said which features should we expect well we should get both 13 and 15in sizes with 16 gigs of RAM confirmed for sure seeing as Apple already upgraded the M3 models for free with 16 gigs and right now you can get one for 900 bucks on Amazon which is crazy link below but the M4 Chip is going to be a beast in this MacBook year and we know for sure it's going to come with a 10 core CPU version and 10 core GP CPU which is just nuts it's crazy powerful and I'm worried that it's going to cause some thermal throttling and overheating so subscribe for those testing videos but other than that we're not expecting very much probably the 12 megapixel Center Stage camera maybe some other spec updates and the same $1,100 price tag now the second product is the iPhone se4 and we've been seeing tons of leaks for this new model and they keep getting better and better including design leaks spec leaks with being the first product with Apple's custom modem and so much more but first let me show you a new smartphone gimbal that surprised me in multiple ways this is the I steady M7 3 AIS AI tracking smartphone gimbal from our sponsor hem who revolutionized the gimbal industry with features that level up your creativity the first cool feature is the magnetic interface control that you can keep in your hand if you have't in Stand mode and you have full control of the gimbal with a 1. 4 in touchscreen what's nice is that it has AI tracking without needing app control so a simple okay hand signal will start tracking and an open Palm to stop which works really fast and accurately and follows you around 360¬∞ and it comes with an RGB fill light for warm or cool lighting that's 50% brighter than before another cool feature is this detachable remote controller that shows you a real-time preview and you can select people pets and even objects which is cool and all this works with your default camera Instagram Tik Tok or any other app which is awesome and there's definitely so much more that this thing can do and if you're interested go ahead and click the links in the description below to learn more now getting back to the iPhone se4 this one is rumored to come in March of next year which the SE has always coming in the spring so it's technically still an early Apple event we're expecting a modern redesign based on the iPhone 14 design with an edgo edge 6.1 in OLED display for the first time getting rid of that home button adding face ID the USBC port a single 48 megapixel camera which should be a massive upgrade the a18 chip which is huge for performance and with 8 gigs of RAM for Apple intelligence support and the first edition custom Apple modem and we just got to report that Apple has to stop selling the current iPhone SE in the EU because it still has a lightning port so they're going to remove it from the Apple online store on December 20th which means that Apple must release the new iPhone SE as soon as possible so early 2025 now for product number three we're getting new iPad Air models and Mark Gman back in October said that we're getting an 11-in and 13-in model and he claimed it's coming in early 2025 around the launch time of the iPhone se4 which of course is March for these new iPads we're basically getting more internal improvements nothing major so an M3 chip upgraded from the M2 and not a lot of design changes or maybe no design change at all so it's going to be pretty much a very boring update and my take is that if you're willing to get the iPad Air just go for the M4 iPad Pro moving on to product number four like I mentioned before the new Mac Studio could be coming as soon as March which is still early 2025 and it's going to come with the new M4 Max chip and the brand new M4 Ultra with Thunderbolt 5 support with with up to six ports which is crazy better display support probably 8K 120 upgraded specs and much better performance with that new M4 Ultra chip being the world's fastest production CPU and maybe even GPU beating out nvidia's RTX 490 moving on to product number five we have a new entrylevel iPad which first Mark Gman said it might not come into later next year but his most recent update says spring of 2025 alongside the new iPhone se4 and IP P air now this one's going to have roughly the same design but with a speed boost with a new chip at least an a16 and maybe even A7 Pro if they want to give it Apple intelligence support but seeing as the iPad Mini has the a177 pro I don't think Apple's going to bring it to the budget iPad they might just stick to the a16 and with that change we can expect the price to stay at the same $349 or they might even drop it to $2.99 which would be awesome now for product number six we have a new magic keyboard for either the budget iPad or the iPad Air it's currently unknown which one or maybe they'll give a new magic keyboard for both of them the new version is going to likely have the function key row which is awesome and it likely will not be as fancy as the iPad PR's new magic keyboard with the aluminum top case so it's going to be somewhere in the middle with a similar kind of rubbery plastic design but with a couple of extra upgrades like maybe a larger trackpad and of course those function keys and finally for product number seven we have the new Air tags 2 code named b58 n discovered by Mark German now it's been already probably 4 years since the original air tags came out in the spring of 2021 and now we're expecting them once again in the first half of 2025 according to Mark gurman and in my opinion I think the spring makes the most sense since that's when it came out originally in terms of new features we're expecting enhanced location tracking capabilities with a new chip which means it could have second gen Ultra wideband built in which came with the iPhone 15 lineup now Ming quo said that the new Air tag should be going into mass production in late 2024 which is basically right now and they might even have really good integration with Apple's Vision Pro headset which is quite interesting I guess that means you might be able to literally put on the headset and see the air tags through objects like under your couch which would be incredible so with that said those were seven new products to expect in early 2025 potentially with an Apple event so let me know which one you're excited about down in the comment section below and subscribe for more videos like this one thanks for watching and we'll see you in the next one Vessi, here in Vancouver, we learned these past couple of weeks that just because it's June, doesn't mean we're free of rainstorms quite yet. But thankfully we have a secret weapon, Vessi. They claim their shoes are extremely waterproof thanks to their Dymotex technology. So even that June monsoon won't leave us shaking in our boots. The Stormburst shoes are now available in low profile form so they're breathable and comfortable in the summer. It's rugged rubber outsole with extra grip means you can take on the trails, bike on the beach, or simply get to work without a second thought. Head over to vessi.com/linustechtips and get 15% off your first purchase. If you guys enjoyed this video why not check out the time I built a computer at a tech mall in China.

column2: Science Technology Trolley Project #project
Old Intel #PC forgets how to boot! (easy BIOS fix) #technology #tech #shorts
column3: This dusty pc with Intel tech from 300 years ago, sat for so long it forgot what hard drive it was supposed to boot from because the CMOS battery died. Technology hasn‚Äôt changed much since the Stone Age so this fix was easy and involved a few clicks of my mouse. Now this computer is ready to do whatever mundane tasks it‚Äôs asked to do. Just very slowly and with a dying HDD.
column13: this Dusty desktop that dates from the Great Depression has a doomed Drive due to dead sectors diluting the data but that's not what's causing this Dreadful message because though the boot Drive is older than your crusty bed sheets it's still healthy and functional something that can't be said about your previous relationship no the reason this Stone AG box is stuck in limbo is because it forgot where to boot from but before I start poking around with my tool I got to give this box a blowout back before I be get bronchitis and with the the assistance of your sister's toothbrush I'm finally ready to troubleshoot what's bound to be the most complex conundrum I've ever had to face the greatest technician that's ever lived so why did this happen well you know what they say use it or lose it and although you've permanently lost it computers don't have that problem because of something called a seos battery which is the same kind of battery that powers your turbo fleslight this battery makes the BIOS remember its boot settings so when it dies you have to set it up again like I just did

column13: fourth Industrial Revolution four IR let's first define what technological revolution is technological revolution is a period in which one or more technologies is replaced by another technology in a short amount of time it is an era of accelerated technological progress characterized by new innovations whose rapid application and diffusion caused an abrupt change in society one first Industrial Revolution the first Industrial Revolution used water and steam power to mechanize production the first Industrial Revolution the major shift of technological socio-economic and cultural conditions in the late 18th century an early 19th century that began in Britain and spread throughout the world to Second Industrial Revolution the Second Industrial Revolution 1871 to 1914 the second used electric power to create mass production the Second Industrial Revolution was another great leap forward in technology in society new innovations in steel production petroleum and electricity led to the introduction of public automobiles and airplanes in this lesson learn about the key inventions that spurred this revolution three third Industrial Revolution the third Industrial Revolution the sweeping changes brought about by computing and communication technology starting from circa 1950 with the creation of the first general-purpose electronic computers the third used electronics and information technology to automate production the third Industrial Revolution how lateral power is transforming energy the economy and the world is a book by Jeremy Rifkin published in 2011 the premise of the book is that fundamental economic change occurs when new communication technologies converge with new energy regimes mainly renewable electricity now the four Industrial Revolution 4ir fourth Industrial Revolution is building on the third the digital revolution that has been occurring since the middle of the last century it is characterized by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical digital and biological spheres there are three reasons why today's transformations represent not merely a prolongation of the third Industrial Revolution but rather the arrival of a fourth and distinct one velocity scope and systems impact the speed of current breakthroughs has no historical precedent when compared with previous industrial revolutions the fourth is evolving at an exponential rather than a linear pace moreover it is disrupting almost every industry in every country and the breadth and depth of these changes herald the transformation of entire systems of production management and governance the fourth Industrial Revolution for I are characterized by the fusion of the digital biological and physical worlds as well as the growing utilization of new technologies such as artificial intelligence cloud computing robotics 3d printing the Internet of Things and advanced wireless technologies among others has ushered in a new era of economic disruption with uncertain socio-economic consequences for Africa however Africa has been left behind during the past industrial revolutions the fourth Industrial Revolution finally will change not only what we do but also who we are it will affect our identity and all the issues associated with it our sense of privacy our notions of ownership our consumption patterns the time we devote to work and leisure and how we develop our careers cultivate our skills meet people and nurture relationships it is already changing our health and leading to a quantified self and sooner than we think it may lead to human augmentation the list is endless because it is bound only by our imagination please subscribe and like Timothy

findings uncover a world where ancient Builders achieved astonishing Feats that still puzzle us how did they achieve such incredible Precision without modern tools What secrets did they uncover about the universe join us as we uncover ancient technologies that defy the laws of physics the hidden Technologies of past civilizations ancient civilizations achieved incredible Feats in construction technology and science they built enormous pyramids temples and other structures with astonishing Precision for instance the pyramids of Egypt feature blocks weighing up to 200 tons meticulously transported and placed with Incredible accuracy these civilizations also developed advanced irrigation systems metal working techniques and medical practices the Egyptians Mayans and Mesopotamians created tools and weapons that continue to amaze us Roman Engineers designed designed aqueducts that used gravity to transport water over vast distances showcasing their Advanced understanding of hydraulics the Mayans developed highly detailed calendars and had a deep knowledge of astronomical Cycles which influenced their Agriculture and ceremonies meanwhile the Chinese invented Technologies such as paper Gunpowder the compass and printing long before these became common in the west exploring the technological capabilities of ancient civilizations reveals their remarkable advancements by examining their tools materials and methods we can gain a deeper appreciation of their Ingenuity much like researchers Randall Carlson and Shawn Ryan have done researchers are fascinated by the ways ancient people built structures and crafted tools without the help of modern machinery they study ancient construction techniques to learn how our ancestors moved massive Stones by examining artifacts they gain insights into the materials and methods used in ancient craftsmanship the process of reverse engine engineering involves taking something apart to see how it works and then recreating it when applied to ancient Technologies it means trying to understand how ancient people built things and then attempting to recreate those processes using modern tools and knowledge reverse engineering ancient Technologies can teach us a lot about the knowledge of ancient cultures it helps preserve cultural heritage and can even Inspire modern Innovation by showing us how ancient tools and techniques worked by recreating these ancient methods researchers can connect with the past and uncover new ideas for the future people can discover fascinating insights by studying the science and engineering of ancient civilizations understanding and recreating their Technologies not only helps us preserve the ways ancient people lived and worked but also Sparks new ideas and improves our modern technology for instance examining ancient Water Management Systems might inspire better methods for conserving and using water today ancient civil izations like the Egyptians Greeks Romans and Chinese made remarkable technological advancements the Egyptians for example engineered the pyramids with such Precision that their construction methods are still studied today the Greeks developed early forms of analog computers like the antira mechanism which could predict astronomical positions Romans were masters of civil engineering creating extensive Aqueduct systems that supplied water to cities the Chinese invented paper gunpowder and Compass which revolutionize navigation and communication when researchers want to reverse engineer in ancient technology they follow a careful and pollution to address these challenges the Navy is exploring Advanced Technologies aimed at minimizing fuel consumption and reducing pollution by adopting such Innovations they not only aim to cut various industrial sectors including factories power plants and large-scale companies are also eyeing this technology these industries operate heavy machinery and engines that consume substantial energy and emit pollutants they are constantly seeking ways to enhance efficiency and reduce costs introducing advanced technology to improve the performance and cleanliness of their operations holds promise in achieving these objectives public demonstrations have showcased how this technology can be tailored to suit industrial needs further sparking interest and exploration in its potential applications at the conferences representatives from VAR ious Industries witnessed firsthand how technology could revolutionize their operations for instance power plants could utilize this technology to enhance electricity generation efficiency while factories could employ it to significantly reduce emissions during production the widespread interest in these demonstrations highlights the Technology's numerous potential applications moreover these public showcases serve to promote awareness and Adoption of the technology attendees at these conferences can return to their companies and organizations to share their Newfound knowledge fostering broader interest and Paving the way for more widespread adoption on Shawn Ryan's show the ancient practice of alchemical science was discussed in depth Alchemy originating in ancient Egypt India China Greece and the Islamic world and reaching its Zenith in medieval Europe combines chemistry physics astrology art Metallurgy medicine and Mystic ISM the primary goal of alchemy was to achieve transmutation transforming base materials like lead into Noble ones such as gold Central to alchemical Pursuits was the Quest for the philosopher stone believed to Grant immortality and perfect health modern science now explains transmutation through Atomic level changes atoms the fundamental building blocks of matter consist of protons in their nuclei and elements are defined by specific types of atoms transmutation involves altering the number of protons in an atom's nucleus thereby changing it into a different element this phenomenon occurs naturally such as in radioactive decay or artificially through controlled nuclear reactions in the recent tests of a new technology scientists observe potential changes at the atomic level these tests hinted that transmutations where atoms transform from one element to another could be occurring this breakthrough suggests that technology might influence the fundamental structure of material during these experiments researchers noted decreases in some elements and increases in others for instance they observed less common elements like iron and more rarer ones such as gold or silver this event implies that the technology can alter Atomic compositions what's particularly remarkable is that these Transformations seem to happen at room temperature normally converting one element into another requires extreme conditions like those found in nuclear reactors or Stars achieving this at lower temperatures could revolutionize various Industries the implications are vast this technology could potentially be used in manufacturing to create valuable materials from more abundant ones it might also find applications in Waste Management by converting hazardous materials into harmless substances furthermore it holds promise in energy production if it can facilitate Atomic level changes it could lead to the development of more efficient batteries or fuel cells this could significantly reduce our dependence on fossil fu fuels and mitigate greenhouse gas emissions transmutation opens up engaging possibilities for changing one element into another challenging our understanding of matter and energy in the physical world exploring this potential could revolutionize physics and chemistry offering deeper insights into the universe's fundamental components moreover this technology holds promise in medical advancements by altering the atomic structure of substances it could pave the way for creating novel medicines and therapies imagine breakthroughs in treating diseases and accelerating healing processes through such Innovations yet alongside these prospects come significant risks manipulating atoms at such a precise level involves complex processes that remain largely mysterious potential dangers like unintended radiation emissions or the creation of hazardous byproducts underscore the need for rigorous research and testing to harness the benefits while mitigating risks collaboration across disciplines physics chemistry and Engineering is essential the thunderstorm generator Secrets Randall Carlson discussed a fascinating device known as a thunderstorm generator which boasts incredible power this machine as detailed in an exciting video featuring George Lush a contractor for Aerospace Industries including NASA was developed in England the purpose of the thunderstorm generator is to replicate thunderstorms by artificially creating the necessary atmospheric conditions at its core the generator comprises several key components the primary particle beam acts like a high-speed particle launcher essential for initiating storm-like conditions magnetic fields that can adjust their strength and direction play a crucial role in guiding these particles precisely additionally a secondary particle beam Works in tandem with the primary beam to stabilize and amplify the storm simulation throughout the device strategically placed sensors and detectors continuously monitor particles movement magnetic field variations and other critical parameters this data is vital for scientists to fine-tune the generator's operation and deepen their understanding of its capabilities the control systems which act as the brains of the operation oversee all these components to ensure they work together smoothly a robust and dependable energy source is essential to power the generator given its high energy demands for creating thunderstorms the thunderstorm generator resides within a large specialized building designed to Shield it from external elements and potential hazards inside the primary particle beam is housed in a long cylindrical chamber where particles are accelerated using powerful energy sources such as lasers or electric fields surrounding this chamber are modulating magnetic fields arranged to precisely guide the high-speed particles near the primary beam a secondary particle beam assists in maintaining a stable flow of particles sensors and detectors scattered throughout the generator continuously measure parameters like temperature pressure and particle movement this real-time data is crucial for making adjustments on the Fly and understanding the generated event in the central control room equipped with Advanced Computers and monitors scientists manage the generators operations these Control Systems enable precise adjustments of timing power levels and other critical settings to ensure Optimal Performance the energy source typically a powerful generator or connected to a high capacity electri electrical grid supplies the necessary power to operate the machine when the generator is active the main particle beam emits particles controlled by magnetic fields a secondary beam AIDS in stabilizing this process mimicking conditions similar to a natural thunderstorm with high energy and charged particles sensors continuously monitor these interactions providing valuable data for scientists to refine The Machine's operation and deepen their understanding of the processes involved initially met with significant skepticism from the scientific Community the thunderstorm generator faced doubts about its feasibility in recreating thunderstorms in a controlled lab setting many questioned whether it was technically possible to replicate essential conditions such as high energy levels and charged particles within a machine safety concerns also loomed large given the potential risks associated with generating thunderstorms artificially moreover critics raised doubts about the scientific validity of the generator's results unsure if phenomenal observed in the lab could accurately reflect those of real thunderstorms despite doubts about whether resources should be directed elsewhere in scientific research critics questioned the significant funding energy and materials needed to construct and operate the thunderstorm generator despite these challenges the team persevered they meticulously analyzed complex data collected by sensors and detectors which posed considerable challenges interpreting this data demanded Advanced mathematical and computational tools yet drawing precise conclusions remained elusive the generator occasionally yielded unexpected results prompting further investigation and posing new questions replicating the generator's conditions presented another major obstacle slight adjustments in settings or environmental factors often led to different outcomes hindering consistent replication of results to earn credibility within the scientific Community the team aimed to publish their findings in peer-reviewed journals a rigorous and timeconsuming process demanding robust evidence and compelling explanations what are your thoughts about this new technology that is defying all the laws of physics share your thoughts with us in the comment section below

In the last 10 years, according to official scientific records, Arctic sea ice has been melting at a rate of approximately 12.2% per year. Now, to prevent this Arctic sea ice from melting, a Dutch start up named 'Arctic Reflections' is launching a mega-project that is as ambitious as Mars colonization! They are aiming to refreeze an area of 15.5 million square kilometers, which is equivalent to five times the size of India, within a deadline of just 6 YEARS! For this purpose, quite paradoxically, they are planning to spray salty water, known as brine, over the entire snow-covered North Pole.
For those who don't know, brine‚Äîtraditionally called salty water‚Äîis typically used by all snow-covered countries to prevent snow from freezing on their roads . Because when snow falls, it melts as soon as it comes into contact with this brine. So, how are these scientists going to refreeze snow, which melts the ice? Let's find out!

column2: What is a raspberry pi and why do companies use it? #tech #techskills
column13: have you ever wondered what exactly is Raspberry Pi in simple terms no I'm not speaking about the one you eat I'm speaking about this one a small Affordable Computer and why would you use it why do companies use it I mean it doesn't come with a screen a keyboard a mouse nothing well here's a real world example of why some companies will use raspberry pies okay I love dogs so I'm going to use a real world example of a pet feeder you're going away for a few hours and you want to ensure your dog gets some treats in the meantime you can actually use a Raspberry Pi to control treats getting dispensed from say a treat dispenser you could write a simple program that instructs the Raspberry Pi to activate a motor which in turn would release the pet food at specific time and I know this kind of sounds complex already but honestly these programs that you can write are so simple to do you can write a simple python script and these raspberry pies are really affordable online so think of a Raspberry Pi as a computer board to connect and control other electronic devices or Hardware components
